exercises.instructions_basic:
1. Create three `<h3>` components in your index.html file and add any text you want to each.
2. Use JavaScript to attach a click event listener to each one.
3. When the user clicks on any of the components output the content of that one to the Chrome developer console.
exercises.instructions_stretch: Apply a different CSS style to the `<h3>` when the user hovers over it to change the color of the text
Use square-bracket notation to access the `random_facts` key's value.
Only output the log message if the person works in the finance department.

exercises.instructions_basic:
1. Filter out elements in the following array that are strings and store them in a new array named `onlyStrings`.
     `const junk = [45, "I", true, null, "am", 3.56, "a", undefined, { catchphrase: "Oh hai, Mark"}, "JS", "rockstar"]`

Hint: You can use the `typeof` operator to determine if something is a string.

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/JavaScript/Reference/Operators/typeof
exercises.instructions_stretch: Use and `Array.prototype.reduce()` method to `console.log` a single string with all of the items in the new array.

exercises.instructions_basic:
1. Create a function that logs the result of adding two numbers that were passed in as arguments.
2. Create another function that logs the result of subtracting two numbers that were passed in as arguments.
3. Invoke each function a couple times with different argument values.
exercises.instructions_stretch: Create another function called `calculate` that takes three arguments: two numbers and a function

exercises.instructions_basic: Using Javascript, create a variable to hold your last name. Using the if-else statement, do the following: If your last name has 7 or more letters, console log "I can't pronounce this last name". If your last name has less than 7 characters, console log your last name.
exercises.instructions_stretch: Create a new repository on Github and push the code you wrote up to Github

exercises.instructions_basic:
Create a function called `go` that takes 2 arguments: 
1. direction (forwards, backwards, etc.)
1. speed (mph).

The function, when invoked, will print out the following in your console (for example): `The car is moving forward, at 25 mph.`
exercises.instructions_stretch:
Add a condition inside the function to check if the speed is greater than 75 mph. If it is, add an additional message of SLOW DOWN!

Example:

The car is moving forward at 82 mph
SLOW DOWN!
